target_title: S/MIME: Backup certificate with stronger/better algorithm

note.body:
Stepping through the code with gdb, it looks like the cipher requested by Evolution is blacklisted in NSS now:

```
Thread 1 "evolution" hit Breakpoint 1, SEC_PKCS12CreatePasswordPrivSafe (p12ctxt=p12ctxt@entry=0x561b27b7ae80, pwitem=pwitem@entry=0x7ffe7520b480, privAlg=privAlg@entry=SEC_OID_PKCS12_V2_PBE_WITH_SHA1_AND_40_BIT_RC2_CBC) at p12e.c:359
359     {
(gdb) n
[...]
409             if (!SEC_PKCS12CipherAllowed(privAlg, SEC_OID_UNKNOWN)) {
(gdb) n
399                 PORT_SetError(SEC_ERROR_BAD_EXPORT_ALGORITHM);
```

So the fix would probably to choose something more modern than `SEC_OID_PKCS12_V2_PBE_WITH_SHA1_AND_40_BIT_RC2_CBC`.

target_title: S/MIME: Backup certificate with stronger/better algorithm

I suppose you stopped also the evolution-addressbook-factory, otherwise it could have the book still opened.

As long as the cache.db was recreated, it downloaded the book content from scratch. If the table of the categories is the same, then there might be the contacts with those categories.

sqlite3 cache.db "SELECT ECacheObj FROM ecacheobjects WHERE ECacheObj LIKE '%Project%'"
```

It will show all vCard-s with the `Project` in the content.

GNOME Software in Fedora defaults to install the apps from the "Fedora Flatpak" (it's reflected just below the Install button, showing from where the installation will happen). Does the Software show the Evolution as installed?

When you run from a terminal:

```
   flatpak list | grep Evolution
```

will it have any hit? I believe it will, because the symptoms you describe suggest just that.

There is no problem (of this kind) with the RPM version, you successfully installed it and I guess you can use it, though only if you run it from a terminal, not when you run it from the GUI (if I understand correctly). It can be because the Flatpak-installed app is preferred over the RPM (non-flatpak) apps when using the shortcuts in the GUI. The flatpak app does not install an `evolution` binary, flatpaks are started differently (to not clash with the system-installed binaries), like `flatpak run org.gnome.Evolution`.

target_title: Evolution not starting after Fedora 41 update

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. I agree with Andre, you probably happened to install a Fedora Flatpak version of the Evolution, which does not work well (due to the way it is built in the Fedora Flatpak). It depends what it says when you run that version from a terminal, that is:

```
   flatpak kill org.gnome.Evolution
   flatpak run org.gnome.Evolution
```

(first to kill, to be sure the terminal output will go to the terminal it had been started from). I cannot find an upstream nor downstream bug for it, I'm sorry, I only know it had been reported recently.

You can try to workaround the problem when you start the evolution with disabled sandboxing for the WebKitGTK, like this:

```
   flatpak kill org.gnome.Evolution
   WEBKIT_DISABLE_SANDBOX_THIS_IS_DANGEROUS=1 flatpak run org.gnome.Evolution
```

I suggest you run the Flatpak Evolution, use File->Back Up Evolution Data... in there and then uninstall it from the GNOME Software, then make sure you'll have chosen the RPM version in the GNOME Software (it's just below the Install button), then install it, though I understood you have it already installed. You should be able to restore the created backup in the RPM version of the Evolution.

I do not think this is an Evolution fault, thus I'm closing this, but, please, provide the reason for the crash (should be shown on the terminal), to check whether it's the problem I think of and if not, then I'll reopen this. Thank you in advance.

Filter matching incorrectly on Subject header using wildcard pattern

note.body:
Thank you for clarifying that the "ressemble à" (sounds like) condition is based on a phonetic algorithm and not a textual or pattern-based match. However, the way this option is presented in the interface (especially in non-English translations) can lead to significant confusion. Users may reasonably expect it to work with textual matching, especially since it’s commonly needed in filters.

If this feature is kept, I strongly suggest either:

- Renaming or rephrasing the label to something more explicit, like "phonetic match" instead of "ressemble à," which in French implies textual similarity.
- Adding documentation or a tooltip to clarify its behavior, so users can avoid this misunderstanding.

Alternatively, removing the feature altogether, as you mentioned, might prevent this kind of misinterpretation.

Thank you for considering this feedback, and I appreciate your support in clarifying the issue.

target_title: Filter matching incorrectly on Subject header using wildcard pattern

note.body:
"ressemble à" is "sounds like" in English. It seems to be a [phonetic algorithm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soundex) and thus unrelated to what you want to achieve. (I'd personally vote for removing "sounds like" as I have a hard time to imagine any non-obscure use case for it.)

In your case, I'd set `all the following conditions` with two separate `Subject | contains` conditions.

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. As Andre said, version of the evolution-ews is important here, the "Linux Mint 22 and Ubuntu 24.04." doesn't tell anything about it, I'm sorry, not talking the distros update the packages from time to time.

Anyway, did you try to right-click the calendar in the calendar list and pick Refresh, please? The M365 does not have usable notifications about the server side changes, unlike the EWS protocol, thus the sources are updated in the refresh interval as set in the respective calendar, book,... Properties. The Refresh is there to speed up the refresh. The default interval is to refresh once per hour.

I guess you have 3.52.x, at least on that Ubuntu machine. The current stable version is 3.54.2 and it contains a lot of changes in the Microsoft 365 plugin (it's part of [the evolution-ews project](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evolution-ews/)), including, but not limited to the calendar part. There are some important fixes also in the mail sending. The Microsoft 365 is very new, which is the reason why it's buggy.

note.body:
The problem with EWS is that the Application ID for Evolution must be whitelisted by the organization admin. Trying to masquerade as real Outlook faking its Application ID does not work in my case. However, IMAP is universally allowed. In fact, people may prefer to use IMAP account type because it allows to specify SMTP server (see #2917). Another reason for preferring IMAP over EWS may be firewalls or Microsoft's being a proprietary protocol.

I do not see why Auth2 advanced options should be limited to EWS as I do not see why Outlook users should be prevented from using IMAP transport and forced to use proprietary EWS.

target_title: Missing Tenant-ID and Application-ID fields for IMAP Auth2
Unable to specify alternative SMTP server for Microsoft 365 account type

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. The Microsoft 365 received a lot of (say important) fixes since your version, I know the Ubuntu variants are behind the latest stable series. The latest version is 3.54.2 at the moment. You might be safer with the Exchange Web Services, if your company lets you log in with it.

Nonetheless, both EWS and m365 do not allow to change the sending part. That's on purpose. What you want to do is to create a new Mail account and set its Receiving type to "None", and the Sending part to the SMTP. Then you'll have offered to send from two addresses in the composer. It is possible to disable a `Transport` source in the `~/.config/evolution/sources/` for the EWS/m365, but I'm afraid it'll re-enable it, because there had been bugs about the sub-sources not being properly enabled. It would need testing.

In any case, the extra SMTP send-only account is the way to workaround the requirements, you only need to take care which account you send the messages with. You can set up a Send Account overrides in the Edit->Preferences->Composer Preferences->Send Account tab.

target_title: Pressing Space at the end of an email no longer moves to the next unread one

note.body:
Right, as long as it scrolls up/down the focus is alright.

It's funny, there is 1 pixel difference. The WebKitGTK says the space to scroll vertically is 1011 pixels. The scroll position is 484 pixels and the page has 526 pixels visible height, which makes 484+526=1010 pixels at the bottom of the visible range (thus missing a single pixel to be scrolled).

I cannot reproduce it here, even when I fiddle with the window height and the scroll bar position to be at that single pixel, the WebKit scrolls that pixel as expected. Nonetheless, I've [a new test patch](/uploads/00791d196d501cdfe645cab08e572a56/debug.patch) and I'd like to ask you to give it a try. It's generated from the source code, thus it's applied differently:
```
   cd /usr/share/evolution/webkit/
   sudo patch -p3 </tmp/debug.patch
```

it contains also the previous changes, which need to be reverted first: `cd /; sudo patch -p0 -R </tmp/debug.patch` Hrm, I see naming the patches the same was not the best idea.

target_title: Use a different keyring to store passwords

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. If there is anything to be added for this, then it would be "all accounts or no accounts". Trying to get the "proper store" for each account separately I'd really not even try to think of.

There is used libsecret under the hood. One thing, it is not only Evolution, there are related also the evolution-data-server background processes (try `ps ax | grep evolution` to see them). Each may want to get to the password. Only the GUI apps (like the Evolution or a gnome-calendar) can ask for those passwords. The secrets canbe stored for the current session only or in a provided collection. I do not know whether the collections can have their own password on the libsecret library level, it's done somwhow in it or in the gnome-keyring (or any other libsecret D-Bus API implementation).

The evolution-data-server sources contain the `src/libedataserver/e-secret-store.c`, where all these things are done. It's not about the code change, in short, replace `SECRET_COLLECTION_DEFAULT` with something else, but I see the libsecret API has it only when storing the secret, not when reading it neither when deleting it. That could be a problem, your other users might be asked for the password of the other keyring without any intention from their side.

Letting that apart, it would be still a problem to debug this on user machines where the user could unintentionally change the keyring name in the settings or any such thing.

That being said, I agree with Andre, this is nothing for the Evolution code. There are already existing mechanisms how to safely separate user data (not only secrets). If you want to share also files with the other users, then use "shareable" directories. Trying to address one specific use case, in a very core part of the app, with a chance to break the things for the other users (by those users, unintentionally), is something I prefer not to do.

For example, in the shared computer on my house where I do not access evolution email frequently, the email password would be secure most of the time, encrypted with a special password that is not shared with everyone. After using it I can lock the keyring and that will keep the computer just working as expected (as the login keyring is still unlocked) and the passwords are secure again.

Autocrypt header uses wrong email address

note.body:
From the very start of [the autcorypt header spec](https://docs.autocrypt.org/level1.html#the-autocrypt-header):

```
The addr attribute is mandatory, and contains the single recipient
address this header is valid for. If this address differs from
the one in the From header, the entire Autocrypt header MUST be
treated as invalid.
```

Thus the value has some meaning. It just doesn't feel right to simply write the `From` address into the `addr` parameter before sending, because that can be wrong. Evolution writes there the address the key was found for, which is done when changing the `From` address with the combo box. It does not update it when changing the From" entry in the "From override" section.

> I only use one key

I  know some users have different keys for different addresses, some, as you, have multiple addresses defined in a single key. The "lookup for the key with an email address instead of using a single key ID in the preferences" had been added for those with multiple keys and multiple aliases.

Doing this on the identity change allows to show a warning when the key is too long for the Autocrypt header.

These things would need semi-heavy changing to make it work differently, like to set the Autocrypt header only before sending, in time of the question whether the Autocrypt header should be send or not. I'm not saying it's any big obstacle, just that it exists.

Thanks for the quick reply.
 
Milan Crha commented: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evolution/-/issues/2905#note_2278553
 
> > Instead evolution should use the account address for retrieving the
> > gpg-key but use the from address for the addr= value.
>
> I'm afraid that would lead to another error, the email address in the
> Autocrypt header won't match the gpg key email address.

My understanding that isn't a problem according to the specification. [From the
FAQ](https://docs.autocrypt.org/faq.html#why-do-you-use-the-addr-attribute-rather-than-the-uid-from-the-key):

> We want to be able to handle the header without having to parse the key first.
> We believe that using the ‘addr’ attribute will be more forward compatible.
> For example we discussed hashing the uid in the Level 1 PGP keys so in case
> they leak to keyservers they do not leak the e-mail address. This would not be
> compatible with requiring the e-mail address as the uid.

> Would it work if the Autocrypt header is not used when the gpg's key
> email address does not match the From email address?

The most important case for me is I change the From to an email address
that is also one of my gpg key's e-mail addresses. Then Autocrypt
header should be there and the addr attribute should match the From.

I would prefer to have the Autocrypt header on e-mail addresses I
haven't added manually to my gpg key and I would prefer to not expose
e-mail addresses that I'm not currently using as my from by Autocrypt's
embeded gpg kek.

So yes, I would be ok, if the Autocrypt header is removed, if the email
address isn't in the gpg key. 

> There are two
> things about the key lookup though, one is that the key can be
> specified in the settings, or it's checked from the From address (or
> better from the identity's address), when the composer is opened or
> when the accounts are changed. When the key is specified in the
> settings, it does not look up for the (other) mail.

Personally, I only use one key, that includes different uid's. Even
if changing the From address the key lookup has the same key as from
the settings the attr attribute in the Autocrypt header would need
to change.

note.body: Hello, ok thank you, I await your reply

target_title: Correct certificate key usage constants

note.body:
I figured the `openssl` can create the certificates with the `keyUsage` set with:
```
openssl req -x509 -newkey rsa:4096 -keyout key.pem -out cert.pem -sha256 -days 365 \
    --addext "keyUsage=digitalSignature" \
    --addext "extendedKeyUsage=emailProtection"
```

or

```
openssl req -x509 -newkey rsa:4096 -keyout key.pem -out cert.pem -sha256 -days 365  \
    --addext "keyUsage=Data Encipherment" \
    --addext "extendedKeyUsage=emailProtection"
```

which the `keytool` shows as:

```
#3: ObjectId: 2.5.29.37 Criticality=false
ExtendedKeyUsages [
  emailProtection
]

#4: ObjectId: 2.5.29.15 Criticality=false
KeyUsage [
  DigitalSignature
]
```

and

```
#3: ObjectId: 2.5.29.37 Criticality=false
ExtendedKeyUsages [
  emailProtection
]

#4: ObjectId: 2.5.29.15 Criticality=false
KeyUsage [
  Data_Encipherment
]
```

respectively. I know the `KeyUsage` extension is not marked as "critical" in this case, while with your certificates it is.

The NSS says about the first certificate (the one with the `DigitalSignature`) that it does not have `certificateUsageEmailSigner` neither the `certificateUsageEmailRecipient` bit set, while the second certificate (the one with the `Data_Encipherment`) is claimed with the usage `certificateUsageEmailSigner` by the NSS.

I expected the `Data_Encipherment` would map to a different value.

Looking in the gdb, the certificates `keyUsages` bit-field is set to `0x80` for the sign certificate, which maps to the `certificateUsageUserCertImport`, while the encrypt certificate has set `0x10`, which maps to the `certificateUsageEmailSigner` value in the NSS version 3.100.0.

According to the [GnuTLS documentation](https://www.gnu.org/software/gnutls/reference/gnutls-gnutls.html) the `GNUTLS_KEY_DIGITAL_SIGNATURE` maps to `128`, aka `0x80`, and `GNUTLS_KEY_DATA_ENCIPHERMENT` maps to `16`, aka `0x10`, thus the numeric values are the same, but the names are different in the NSS.

Maybe I did something wrong, I do not know, it just looks like the NSS has incorrect mapping between the stored usage values in the certificate and the bits it provides to the library users. I may stop using the NSS constants and use some own, as a workaround.

target_title: gtk3's gtk_show_uri() doesn't focus browser window under Wayland

note.body:
The issue was resolved by removing the inclusion of `--class=` in the .desktop file. Copying over the debian .desktop file into the ~/.local/share/applications/ folder so KDE wayland would now focus the browser window when clicking a web link in Evolution.  Be sure you also have http and https pointing to your browser in KDE settings as well as your chosen browser as default.

To prevent the .desktop file from being replaced during an update, edit /etc/pacman.conf and add NoUpgrade= to point to the .desktop file I had edited.  This has prevented the file from upgrading during a package update and Evolution passing focus to the browser.  I am pleased to report, this is still working flawlessly with Firefox and Floorp.

As previously mentioned, this issue doesn't occur when using KDE with Flatpak, only when installing the browser from the Arch or a derivative from the AUR.  Installing Evolution from either Arch or Flatpak makes no difference, as the issue is with the browser .desktop file.

target_title: Missing Key Commitment in S/MIME

note.body:
I briefly checked the used API from the NSS library and I do not see anything to verify the returned bits contain any garbage or such thing. It all looks perfectly fine from the currently used API in the libcamel (starting with `NSS_CMSDecoder_Start()`).

I believe the change still should come to the underlying libraries, which know the data they are decryption, while the libcamel only gets the processed/resulting data. One of the gpg issues also needed fixes on the gpg side and any workaround on the libcamel side was a disaster (the gpg fixed it on their side later).

Thus the `NSS_CMSDecoder_Update()` should fail and set appropriate error code for the `PORT_GetError()` function.

[feature] Possibility to undo email management actions?

note.body:
You summarized it quite well. Also note that some actions, and/or for some providers, the actions cannot be undone to an exactly the same state as before doing the action. Like with an IMAP, moving a message to a different folder and back will assign it a different UID on the server (it might not be a big deal, I do not know). Or for recurring events, changing a single instance would require to restore the original content of the master object, but it's not always possible and it can lead to notifications to the attendees, which may or may not be relevant.

Th email part is the largest, others are smaller. The reason for this being initially closed is described in your comment. It's a giant project to provide undo/redo for each action in the code.

It seems to me that some apps allow undo only for a certain period of time (several seconds), when there is an overlay shown with something like "Object removed [ Undo ]", where once the overlay disappears the change is permanent. I suppose they just postpone to save the change until it's "confirmed" by not pressing the Undo button. It's a simpler approach for sure, but it distracts the UI (I cannot image to see an overlay for each Delete/Ctrl+D key press when deleting mail messages in the morning; that would be awfully distracting).

target_title: [feature] Possibility to undo email management actions?

note.body:
I'm another long time Gnome/Evolution user (probably as long as the original Bugzilla bug from 2001) - I've gone back and forth between Thunderbird and Evolution; I keep coming back to Evolution for the Gnome integration but occasionally going back to have Ctrl+Z functionality.

I am a developer (and have done bits and pieces of tracking bugs down in earlier versions of Evolution) and if I thought this would be an easy job I might take a look at it, but it feels like it would be a massive task since for consistency you'd need to do it for almost every UI action in Email, Tasks, Calendar, Memo and Contacts. So you'd need every UI action to store a 'how to reverse' log/callback somewhere that the generic Ctrl+Z function could then run (plus a 'roll-forwards' to implement redo).

If I'm right about the above then it would need the maintainers of all of the various parts to be involved _or_ for one person to be familiar enough with the whole code base to achieve it. 

Is that about right or is there a simpler approach?

target_title: add support for proper copy-pasting of recipients

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. This is a proper copy, it copies what you selected. Pasting into a text editor, you'll see a table-like text being pasted, with the "headings" for From/To/Cc rows. The paste into the name entry cannot know whether the text before the actual address is the recipient name or some "garbage" to be removed.

The only thing I can think of right now is to make the copy function check whether anything selected in the preview panel is a mail address (or more addresses) and add a special for-evolution-internal format into the clipboard containing only the addresses (with their names), and when pasting it into the name entry it would use this new special format instead of the bare text. Some corner cases like only part of the email address being selected and such would be good to cover as well (for me, I'd store the whole address into that new format, even if only a single letter of the email address is selected). And with the "email address" I mean the clickable part, not the recipient name.

note.body:
I do not think `ngettext` can be used everywhere. Is there any particular reason to prefer the `ngettext` or it's just a personal preference?

As it lacks the translation domain argument it uses the process default translation domain, which might not be the right one. Evolution is full of libraries, which can be loaded out of the `evolution` process. It's why exists and there's used `#include <glib/gi18n-lib.h>`. Being explicit about the gettext domain is only for good, not for bad. The safest is to use the glib variant (not talking you do not need a special `#include` for the gettext variant). That's my point of view on this matter.

target_title: Correct certificate key usage constants

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. The changes for the #2345 added check for the key usage when reading the certificate from an address book. It picks the first usable certificate in the list, where the order is not defined (or better to say I cannot define it). The code checks the `certificateUsageEmailRecipient` usage, which I understand as being the one for the encryption, because there is also a key `certificateUsageEmailSigner`.

It's possible some place had been missed, though if it worked a year ago...

You mentioned the recipient certificate is both in an address book and also imported in Edit->Preferences->Certificates->Contact Certificates, is that correct? If you could make a test and run from a terminal:

```
   gsettings set org.gnome.evolution.mail lookup-recipient-certificates off
```

to turn off lookup of the certificates in the address books, then it'll need the recipients' certificates imported in the Evolution. It will show whether this part is broken, or the other, or both. Certificates looked up in the address book have a precedence over those stored locally.

You can run:

```
   gsettings reset org.gnome.evolution.mail lookup-recipient-certificates
```

to return the value back to its default, which is `books`.

> can this “(org.gnome.Evolution:13213): Gdk-WARNING **: 12:39:55.080: Tried to map a popup with a non-top most parent” be skipped, when a tooltip is suppressed over a context menu in wayland?

It's gtk3's fault/warning, not evo's.

> I guess SVG icons, which utilize...

Maybe, I can give it a try. There is no artist in the team, thus it'll be fun. I suppose you meant to have once `light` and once `dark` in the props, otherwise they are the same in your test.

> both menues are constructed differently, as they behave differently.

Correct. See [above](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evolution/-/issues/2890#note_2265419).

> gtk_image_menu_item_set_always_show_image() or additions to .config/gtk-3.0/settings.ini

The former cannot be done, because the menu is constructed by the gtk+ code (from a `GMenuModel`) in the way they prefer, not in the way the app prefers; the later cannot be changed by the app, because it's a user option, thus a user choice (+/- the differences between Wayland and X11 you spotted, which are gtk3 thing again).

----------

The `GMenuModel` is used, because all the gtk+ API goes that way. Pros: unified view on the thing. Cons: it's not that great in the gtk3 and the gtk3 implementation lacks simple things the manually created menus (or those from the old GtkUIManager) can achieve for no price (aka a probably simple fix on the gtk3 side might make those menus look the same).

note.body:
With `GDK_BACKEND=x11 evolution` the context menu of the ToDo bar shows icons, on the left side of the windows there is not a lot of empty space.  Tooltips form the todo bar are shown over the menu.  In the sidebar of the Tasks window the context menu does also show icons, but there is empty space on the left side of the window.

With `GDK_BACKEND=wayland evolution` the context menu of the ToDo bar does not show icons (except a toggle before “Show Tasks without Due date”).  When the menu is open, no tooltips are shown (over the menubar), but this is logged “(org.gnome.Evolution:13213): Gdk-WARNING **: 12:39:55.080: Tried to map a popup with a non-top most parent”. In the context menu of the sidebar in the Tasks window, icons are shown, but there is empty space on the left side of the menu.

https://gitlab.xfce.org/xfce/libxfce4ui/-/issues/38 says that gtk_image_menu_item_set_image() is deprecated,  … “If you want to ensure that your menu items show an icon you are strongly encouraged to use a GtkMenuItem with a GtkImage instead”, … `gtk_image_menu_item_set_always_show_image()` does the trick.  In any case adding to .config/gtk-3.0/settings.ini
```
[Settings]
gtk-button-images=1
gtk-menu-images=1
```
does restore the icons of the context menu in the ToDo bar.  So can evolution set gtk-menu-images=1, use `gtk_image_menu_item_set_always_show_image()`, or alike?

In the context menu of the sidebar of the Tasks window, the icon before Save As and Properties are shown in black or white contours, always opposite to the colour of the menu.  So there is some way to show different icon, based on dark/light mode, or to use transparent SVG icons (thus utilizing `style="color-scheme:light dark"` and `style="color-scheme:light dark"`). https://discourse.gnome.org/t/help-in-adding-symbolic-icons-to-my-application/5904/3 suggests for such SVG icons:

* always use fill, not stroke
* for highlight color to use an opacity of 35% of the fill color, not another color

I cannot have an opinion on the internals of GTK/GDK’s backend, as I do not understand these.  For me it is unclear why one of the menus always does have emtpy space on the left and shows the icons on the right side of the empty space, but the other menu either uses the space on the left for icons, or does not use it for icons (and does not show icons).  Both menus are somehow created in different ways, otherwise they will behave consistently.

So:
- can this “(org.gnome.Evolution:13213): Gdk-WARNING **: 12:39:55.080: Tried to map a popup with a non-top most parent” be skipped, when a tooltip is suppressed over a context menu in wayland?
- I guess SVG icons, which utilize `style="color-scheme:light dark"` and `style="color-scheme:light dark"` are the way to show proper icons in dark and light mode and the switch between the modes likely works only with SVG icons.  Or in some other way this is done correctly for the icon before the Propierties element in context menus.
- both menues are constructed differently, as they behave differently.
- `gtk_image_menu_item_set_always_show_image()` or additions to `.config/gtk-3.0/settings.ini` should show the icons in the context menu of the ToDo bar.

target_title: Microsoft 365 Server is Busy ,  waiting for retry

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. It's a backoff policy enforced by the server. It means the client does a lot of requests and the server asks the client to wait. The server says for how long, which is indicated in the status bar. It can happen the first time, when evolution wants to sync server content locally (not only for the mail, but also for the address books, calendars and so on).

These are not supposed to freeze the user interface, they will just wait until the time comes.

Could you install debuginfo packages for the glib2, libsoup3, evolution-data-server, evolution and evolution-ews, and then, when the app freezes, catch a backtrace using gdb, like below, please?

```
gdb --batch --ex "t a a bt" --pid=`pidof evolution` &>bt.txt
```

Please check the bt.txt for any private information, like passwords, email addresses, server addresses,... I usually search for "pass" at least (quotes for clarity only), before sharing it anywhere.

note.body:
> As it's in the form of the `Matches: X`, not `X matches`, is the `ngettext` appropriate here?

Yes, `ngettext` is still appropriate. Remember that some languages have declinations that depend on the actual number, and not just the English distinction of one vs many. E.g. Polish ends words differently when there are 2 than when there are 5 of them. Looks like this would be the case for Czech as well?

> I mean, the form with the `:` is expected, while the translators can translate it to a `No matches`, `One match`, `Matches: 2`, which would make the visual part inconsistent between the actual values.

What do you display when there are 0 matches? `ngettext` will use the appropriate string depending on the number value you pass it, so that shouldn’t be a problem, right? I mean if translators translate to “No matches” for 0, but your code never reaches a path where the value is zero… :shrug: that translation is just not used?

target_title: Slow Response When Creating/Replying/Forwarding Messages

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. I know the same behavior had been discussed on various places in the past, but I cannot find the pointers to those places right now. The investigation led to the WebKitGTK, I think, but, if I recall correctly, there was no resolution, due to the last of reproducibility. Like in your case, the problem exhibits on one machine, but not on another.

Could you install debuginfo packages for the evolution and some other libraries:
```
   sudo dnf install glib2-debuginfo gtk3-debuginfo libsoup3-debuginfo \
      evolution-data-server-debuginfo evolution-debuginfo \
      --enablerepo=fedora-debuginfo --enablerepo=updates-debuginfo
```
(make sure the debuginfo package versions will match the versions of the installed packages, otherwise they would not work) and then just run Evolution and use it and when it'll get stuck, open a terminal window and run `gdb` from there as this:

```
   gdb --batch --ex "t a a bt" --pid=`pidof evolution` &>bt.txt
```

To get the backtrace of the application, to see what it is doing. Please check the `bt.txt` for any private information, like passwords, email addresses, server addresses,... I usually search for "pass" at least (quotes for clarity only), before sharing it anywhere.

I just recalled a `gpg` command execution could cause similar slowness, when the machine's host name had been changed since the machine was installed. It can be completely unrelated to your problem, the backtrace will show.

note.body:
The above commit is for 3.55.1+

From the commit message and the code comment:

Check whether the From address is one of the enabled configured accounts and
if so, then consider the message as being sent, not received; this fails when
sending from one configured account to another configured account, thus first
guess no received date is a sent mail, which does not work for some providers,
like Maildir, which sets the received date from the filename. Trying address
of the account of the selected folder won't work for On This Computer folders.
In other words, this is a pure guess, which has many counter cases.

> When you open the `seahorse` application, does it show the keyring locked? There should be only one password keyring, `Login` or `Default`. There used to be a problem when there had been two of them, but it's years ago. You use quite recent versions.

The keyring is unlocked and SMTP/IMAP and DAV passwords are present.
I have only the default keyring.

Everything works fine if I set a password on the keyring in seahorse. But if I change the keyring password in seahorse to "" (nothing/empty) only DAV works fine and I'm asked for the IMAP/SMTP password in Evolution.
So the problem happens if I do the steps described here:

https://askubuntu.com/questions/867/how-can-i-stop-being-prompted-to-unlock-the-default-keyring-on-boot
1. Open Applications -> Accessories -> Password and Encryption Keys
2. Right-click on the "default" keyring
3. Select "Change password"
4. Enter your old password and leave the new password blank
5. Press ok, read the security warning, think about it and if you still want to get rid of this dialog, choose "use unsafe storage".

If I set a keyring password again Evolution works fine without asking a PW for IMAP/SMTP.

With other Applications like Element or Nextcloud desktop which credentials are stored in the default keyring the auth works fine if the keyring password is empty/not present.
The problem only exist with IMAP/SMTP for Evolution.

Background why I do this is:
The hard disk is encrypted with LUKS. I rely on this security and therefore want as much convenience as possible and no additional password prompts. So I use autologin in lightdm. But at autologin there is no password provided for my user to automatically unlock the keyring. So I removed the password for the keyring which affects that it is unlocked automatically without a password.

I hope/think it may be easily reproducible by removing the keyring password on your side as described above.

Sorry, It may be a bit unusual and I hope it is now easier to understand.

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. Changing the hovering cursor is not that hard, it can be achieved with [this](/uploads/d5ac422e9329a19493becf894ed9e154/evo.patch), but as soon as the drag starts the cursor changes and it looks bad.

The sizing cursor might make more sense, because the move can be done only up and down, but the meaning of the cursor is different, thus some cursor themes can draw it differently, "breaking" the meaning this request want to use the cursor for ("move up-down" can be drawn differently than "resize up-down").

target_title: Evolution deletes faulty parts of filtering rules instead of letting users fix them, and "Mail folders automatically updated" infobar message can be misleading

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. There had been reported something similar regarding the "auto-correction" of the mail filter rules. It sometimes happens the folder listing incorrectly notifies about a folder unsubscribe, which can lead to this.

The idea of not updating the filter rule and instead provide a hint about broken rules to let the user fix it seems better to me, also to not auto-break the rules even more.

target_title: Evolution crashes at start with `floating point exception`

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. I'm afraid there is nothing Evolution can do about it. It does not use MESA or libEGL or any such things directly, they are used by the WebKitGTK and sometimes even gtk3 (gtk4 for sure). I believe it started after some of the package update. I would try to downgrade the WebKitGTK, aka the libwebkit2gtk-4.1-0 package.

It would be good to get a backtrace of the crash, to know where exactly it crashed. You can do it just by running it under gdb, like this:

```
   gdb --batch evolution --ex r --ex bt --ex "t a a bt"
```

which will run the process, print the backtrace once the process stops (hopefully on the crash, not ona user signal or any other reason), then backtrace of all the threads, then it'll quit.

You can run also as the following, to have more control what to do in the gdb:

```
   gdb evolution --ex r
```

With `   CAMEL_DEBUG=gpg flatpak run org.gnome.Evolution`, here are the last lines of log:

```
status: [GNUPG:] KEYEXPIRED 1702799353
status: [GNUPG:] KEYEXPIRED 1702799353
status: [GNUPG:] KEY_CONSIDERED CB41C3F8652FBE8496317E6FEF55DB53F49E8605 0
status: [GNUPG:] KEY_CONSIDERED 872057B2DC029F4D7E878FA2057B67DD3C16667C 0
status: [GNUPG:] KEY_CONSIDERED AF7B251DA8126C30896FAFF77D398AD45AEEEC93 0
status: [GNUPG:] KEY_CONSIDERED 6EB9C9D23D707BF22980E1785F6EC66D34DF7C1B 0
status: [GNUPG:] PINENTRY_LAUNCHED 607 gnome3 1.3.1 - xterm-256color :0 - 1001/1001 0
status: [GNUPG:] KEY_CONSIDERED 6EB9C9D23D707BF22980E1785F6EC66D34DF7C1B 0
status: [GNUPG:] DECRYPTION_KEY BDD512AD48CF4EABCD669137A7F2FE51269FC9A9 6EB9C9D23D707BF22980E1785F6EC66D34DF7C1B u

target_title: lost inbox

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. The POP accounts can be set to leave the messages on the server, though, if I recall correctly, the default is to delete the messages from the server during download to the machine.

The `On This Computer` messages are stored in `~/.local/share/evolution/mail/local/`, where the `On This Computer/Inbox` is under `/cur` sub-directory.

The POP account stores its cache under `~/.local/share/evolution/mail/<pop-account-uid>/`, thus beside the `local` directory of the `On This Computer` account. It has a `uid-cache` file in itself. The `cache` sub-directory of the POP account can contain some of the messages, but I guess since the `uid-cache` file is most likely empty, so will be the `cache` directory (with respect of the files with the stored messages).

If they are gone from those places, then they can be in the `On This Computer/Trash` or maybe `On This Computer/Junk` folders. Or use View->Show Deleted Messages and View->Show Junk Messages in the Inbox to see whether they are there or not.

It can be the `~/.local/share/evolution/mail/local/folders.db` file has got broken somehow, but I believe it's unlikely, because you had Evolution stopped and these mail files are touched only by the evolution itself. Evolution doe snot expunge deleted messages on its own, you can set it in the Edit->Preferences->Mail Preferences, thus unless you have an auto-expunge set the mails should be in the Trash at least.

Check the directories on the disk, if they have the files, but the GUI does not show them and they are not marked for deletion neither as junk, then the folders.db file is most likely broken in some way.

I would copy the `~/.local/share/evolution/mail/` somewhere, as a backup, before doing anything with those internal evolution files.

note.body:
Note: I think the method of sending as "Markdown as plain text" is somewhat similar to flowed format for the receiver.

When the text
```
If a line is longer than X characters it will be hard-wrapped and for the receiver, in particular on small displays, can be hard to read because they have shorter lines.
```
is sent as plain text, then hard line breaks are inserted, the received email's source looks like
```
If a line is longer than X characters it will be hard-wrapped and for
the receiver, in particular on small displays, can be hard to read
because they have shorter lines.
```
and my mobile email client renders it as
```
If a line is longer than X characters it will be hard-
wrapped and for
the receiver, in particular on small displays, can be hard
to read
because they have shorter lines.
```

However, with "Markdown as plain text" the source looks like
```
If a line is longer than X characters it will be hard-wrapped and for the r=
eceiver, in particular on small displays, can be hard to read because they =
have shorter lines.
```
and my mobile client renders it so that it is wrapped at the screen borders, e.g., 
```
If a line is longer than X characters it will be hard-
wrapped and for the receiver, in particular on small
displays, can be hard to read because they have shorter
lines.
```

Not sure how it behaves with respect to quoting, but just as far as display on mobile devices is concerned, the effect seems to be similar to the format=flowed one.

note.body:
Evolution does not download nor adds contact certificates on its own, as far as I know. An S/MIME signed message contains public key of the certificate, it's not downloaded from the Internet separately.

I do not think you can import a private key without its public part. That would be odd. Still the case you filled this bug for it a mystery for me, because the NSS code claimed the public key is not available between locally known certificates (that it's in the email doesn't mean it's trusted, neither that you confirmed it as trusted locally), and Evolution still found the certificate in the local store. The only way I can think  of is that there is a different certificate for the same email address as this missing certificate has stored in itself. The change I committed for the next release will help with this case.

If you'd like to have the "Save to file..." option in the certificate properties/details, then it can be added. The code for this resides in the evolution-data-server code base, thus maybe if you'd like to file a feature request against that project, then it'll not be forgotten.

target_title: Issue HEAD request on URLs to determine if a browser is desired

note.body:
While I agree with this, I also take this as a price for the generality. It's sort of expected that you'll handle the .ics files in Evolution when you read the mail in the Evolution, but it's not a requirement, users can have set any app to handle `text/calendar` files, not only the Evolution.

Evolution could check whether it's it to handle that type, but even that is not always possible, because for the Flatpak the apps do not have access to the list of the scheme handlers, the portals are hiding this information to the sandboxed apps.

Hence I won't do this, due to the obstacles.

target_title: Automatically try the same username and password combination the first time SMTP is used

note.body:
This bit me again today. While I understand your argument in theory, in practice I still think this would be a good UX improvement to have.

* In my experience it is _extremely_ rare for an account to use different passwords for receiving and sending.  
All the big email providers use a unified account/password for both directions, even paranoid "per-app password" systems like FastMail.

* If you can't trust your SMTP server, I don't see why you could trust your IMAP server.

* It's just frustrating to have to re-enter the password later on, usually at the worst possible time and context (i.e. you "just want to send an email right now", not have to go dig around for a password that you "already provided to the app")

  * you probably do not remember the password anyway, or it's a secure autogenerated hash-like password so you have to go fish it out in some reference file or website/intranet, and maybe fail a couple of times because long case-sensitive autogenerated passwords are easy to mis-type

  * in some cases like FastMail, you can't even access the password again from the web interface (they show you the password _only once,_ and if you didn't write it down somewhere to plan ahead for Evolution re-asking the password for SMTP, then "tough luck!", you have to reset the account and start everything from scratch again)

If you are extra concerned about this, maybe in the password prompt dialog you could add a checkbox for "[x] Reuse the same password for sending emails via SMTP", but I would find that checkbox unnecessary personally (because again, I've yet to encounter a single email service that uses separate passwords for SMTP than IMAP) generally; on the other hand, having such a checkbox _could_ allow solving issue #2251 without side-effects.

target_title: regression on "parsing message"?

note.body:
I'd need to see the backtrace, to see what evo is waiting for, but with flatpak it's harder.

It can be evo is trying to figure out whether the included key is in the user's gpg keys. If not, evo suggests to import it. This is calling gpg in the same way as any other gpg communication.

Maybe, the next time it'll happen, could you check whether there's any `gpg` running, and maybe with what arguments? It can be done with `ps ax | grep gpg`.

You can also run Evolution with the gpg debugging on, as:
```
   flatpak kill org.gnome.Evolution
   CAMEL_DEBUG=gpg flatpak run org.gnome.Evolution
```

note.body:
> You wrote EWS will be available to paid accounts only

Not quite. The standalone Exchange servers will still support the EWS protocol, but sometime next year or maybe later Microsoft will disable EWS for all accounts connecting to the office365.com servers, requiring the users to use the new Microsoft Graph API.

For IMAP+SMTP, it works already, even in that ancient 3.44.4, simply File->News->Mail Account->fill the `@hotmail.com` address (I used `@outlook.com`, but there might not be any difference), keep the "Lookup setup options check at the bottom checked and click the "Next" button. Once it autodetects the setting click "Revise Details" button (at the top, most likely) and verify both IMAP and SMTP have set "OAuth2 (Outlook)" authentication method. Then finish the wizard and you'll be asked to log in to the Microsoft account. The mail account did not get it right after this first setup and stayed disconnected with "something is wrong" icon, but when I right-clicked it and picked "Refresh" it connected to the server and showed my mails. This is with 3.52.4, which contains at least one fix in this regard in compare to the 3.44.4.

I suggest to use as new Evolution as possible. If you need to stay with the old Ubuntu (22.04 means it had been released in April 2022, more than 2 years ago), then I suggest to install a Flatpak version, which has its downsides, but it perfectly fits this situation. It's [on the flathub.org site](https://flathub.org/apps/org.gnome.Evolution), where you can also read how to set it up in your distro. They have nice setup steps for many distros.

target_title: Unable to have access hotmail (free) accounts using Evolution

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. There is nothing Evolution(-ews) can do about it, unfortunately. The Microsoft chose to stop developing the Exchange Web Services (EWS) protocol and it'll disable it for the office365.com servers in a year or so, thus the EWS account type will be unusable after it. The Azure portal reflects it (no way to add the EWS protocol). They also made server-side changes preventing free accounts to log in with the EWS. It's a known issue on their side. I do not follow it closely, thus I cannot tell whether they made any progress here. 

Nonetheless, you do not need to create your own app on the Azure server, the wiki page has available three different app ID-s, where usually the third works, but it might be for the school/organizational accounts, not for free accounts. The Microsoft creates a lot of obstacles for the EWS protocol, not only for the free accounts.

The Microsoft's "way to go" is to switch to a new Microsoft Graph API for the office365.com servers. The evolution-ews project provides it as a "Microsoft 365" (M365) account type. You want the 3.54.0 version for it, because it contains many fixes, with the upcoming 3.54.1 release containing even more fixes. The M365 is very new, it needs more testing and there are also limitations on the protocol side, but it should let you log in.

If you are interested in the mail only, you can configure the account as IMAP+SMTP, which has an OAuth2 authentication method too.

target_title: Large local folders display no mail until data is loaded and folder reopened

note.body:
Evolution does all of that, it shows "Generating message list" activities both in the message list and in the status bar (do you have status bar visible?). It also can refresh the message list when needed, but it also depends on the mail provider, whether it provides the information in chunks or not.

I understood the GUI is not frozen, you can move between folders, it's only there is no indication evolution is going anything and the message list is empty until some initial refresh is finished.

I think the best would be to get a backtrace of the evolution process in this "busy with no feedback" state, to see what it is doing in the background. I suppose it's using higher CPU, but maybe not. To get a usable backtrace, install debuginfo packages for evolution-data-server (libcamel in particular, if your distro splits it out into a separate package), then for glib2 and evolution. Then you can run gdb as follows:

```
  gdb --batch --ex "t a a bt" --pid=`pidof evolution` &>bt.txt
```

Please check the bt.txt for any private information, like passwords, email addresses, server addresses,... I usually search for "pass" at least (quotes for clarity only), before sharing it anywhere.

note.body:
The local database is a few GBs in size containing a few thousand e-mails, on a modern PC with an SSD, so no issue there. Also no other software is accessing the DB files, not even an indexer. Unfortunately I couldn't reproduce the issue running in a terminal, everything was snappy this time. Evolution is now at 3.54.0, but I noticed the issue multiple times before reporting, spanning multiple versions.

The main issue is not the mail doesn't get shown quick enough, but when it happens, there is no indication there is (about to be) mail in a folder, while apparently Evolution loads the necessary data silently in the background. Inbetween it is displaying an empty folder, and after loading also fails to refresh the active view. None of these two should happen. Firstly, GUI should detect something is going on and not display an empty folder - which is false information. User could potentially delete it, believing it is empty when it is actually not. Secondly, even if a data load/process operation is late, GUI should refresh the active view when the newly-acquired data is relevant to it.

Will check for errors and notice if it happens again.

note.body:
I see this ticket is closed but I would like to bump it again as this is a critical set of features for myself and few other users I know. 
What would already make a big change would be expanding the functionalities of "Templates" so that:

1. The templates could be labeled/named - often one needs to have a set of different templates with the same subject line (different templates for different groups of recipients). Current system of having templates listed by subject-line only makes it very difficult to manage them.

2. Add a button for responding with template directly to the message panel (to be activated if Template plugin is enabled in preferences)

3. Add and document available variables (see variables available in Quicktext: https://github.com/jobisoft/quicktext/wiki/List-of-all-supported-tags). My top priority is the variable [[FROM=firstname]], in addition to [[FROM=fullname]] already available in Templates - so response can be automatically addressed to original sender.

4. Keep original message to which one is responding below the template, formatted as responded message, and including orig. message header.
---------------
Happy to provide more specifications if needed. Thanks for consideration, I know it is not little to ask.

The error you get from valgrind is something I did not see before. No idea what to do with it, I'm sorry.

Another similar tool allowing memory checking is ASAN. It's not that expensive on CPU. You can run these commands in the terminal:

```
export G_SLICE=always-malloc
export ASAN_OPTIONS=abort_on_error=0:detect_stack_use_after_return=0:detect_leaks=0:handle_segv=0:check_printf=0:detect_deadlocks=1:replace_str=1:replace_intrin=1:alloc_dealloc_mismatch=1:new_delete_type_mismatch=1:detect_container_overflow=1:symbolize=1:quarantine_size_mb=512:thread_local_quarantine_size_kb=1024
export LD_PRELOAD=/usr/lib/libasan.so

/usr/lib/evolution-calendar-factory -w
```

You might have installed that `/usr/lib/libasan.so`, but if not, install it first. I do not know which package provides it in the Arch Linux, I'm sorry.

target_title: IMAP does not have OAuth authentication option

note.body:
@mcrha @dilyan.palauzov In theory, this has been solved for some time...

Per [RFC 7628](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7628.html#section-3.2.2), failed authentication using the SASL OAUTHBEARER method will often enough inform you of both the required scope and the metadata URI of the authentication server, which may then contain a URI for registering one's own client, along with everything else necessary.

Dovecot SASL has also supported this for quite some time, so anyone could simply deploy the relevant server-side. ([Relevant config](https://doc.dovecot.org/2.3/configuration_manual/authentication/oauth2/#full-config-file))

In practice however, there is almost no MUA support for this, which is unfortunate. I guess that is also partially due to historical reliance on configuration files for how to connect to a service? ([RFC 6186](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6186) has seen almost no implementation as well, although many larger companies support it and Evolution uses it for Collection Accounts)

As it stands right now, any full-fledged MUA offering standards-based modern autoconfiguration would become THE recommendation for authentication in universities, schools, etc. (basically anyplace that has not moved to MS365 for, in part, this reason and compliance)

I have also tried to look into it, but honestly the evolution source code scares me :smile:

note.body:
Even, rather than work around it, could I ask you to test to catch with valgrind whether there's any use-after-free or any such thing in the code, please? When you install valgrind and debuginfo packages for libsoup3, evolution-data-server, glib2 and glib-networking (maybe you have them already installed), and then:
1. close Evolution
2. run in a terminal:
```
valgrind --num-callers=30 --leak-check=no --track-origins=yes /usr/libexec/evolution-calendar-factory -w
```
3. wait until the factory is fully started and then run Evolution
```
gdbus wait --session --timeout=120 org.gnome.evolution.dataserver.Calendar8 && evolution
```

Then try to reproduce the problem. The valgrind does a lot of memory checking, which is expensive and slow, thus count with a high CPU use and very slow response from the factory, which can avoid reproducing the problem. If you've any idea which calendar causes the problem, then simply right-click it and pick Refresh from the context menu, to make it run the code if it'll take too long to be run on its own.

Valgrind can avoid crashes of certain issues, thus even if the factory will not crash this time, the valgrind terminal can contain information about the memory issue caused in the code.

In case you use Arch Linux, see https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Debug_-_Getting_Traces

debugging logs for troubleshooting pipe-to-program email filter

note.body:
Understood and fixed the problem.

Cause: the rule `<rule enabled="true" grouping="all" source="incoming" account-uid="0638a333a314d7b7183e80a4d2932233b33ab6c8">` contains an additional attribute `account-uid="0638a333a314d7b7183e80a4d2932233b33ab6c8"` which was not a problem with the previous version, but has become a problem with 3.54.0.

Fix: removing the extraneous attribute and reboot.

The external filter works again.

Mail: Show inline images with 'name' as attachments

note.body:
Attachments which can be shown in the body (like images, text files and so on) have "their line" below the message body, with a button to view them inline. There is currently no way to have an attachment, which would not add this line when it can be shown by the WebKitGTK, but I agree it could some part of this problem.

Could you check the message structure, please? You can right-click the message and save to a file, say `/tmp/msg.msg` and then run from a terminal:

```
   cat /tmp/msg.msg | grep -i -C1 content-
```

, please? The result may contain private information, like the file names and such, thus change them (not remove) to something else, please; it can by just `a.a` as the file name, to denote any such parameter exists in the mail.

target_title: Mail: Show inline images with 'name' as attachments

note.body:
After upgrading to Evo 3.54 I'm seeing this as well, in almost every email I get because my work requires me to use EWS and it seems Outlook/Exchange loves to do this.  It's pretty annoying.  As the mail is in the process of being displayed I first see a series of image attachments, many of them little icons and some very large (like a user's photo or something), and they scroll down and finally the message itself is displayed.

I understand why it was done but maybe the UI for attachments could be handled differently.

For example, the "attachment bar" in the composer is a good model where it's just a single bar at the bottom, which is hidden by default, that contains all the attachments.  Then you expand it if you want to see the attachments.

Or, it could even be part of a left-click menu or something like that.

Thanks for your work on Evolution Milan, it's a lifesaver for me!!
